history.content:
Did you take data 8? I believe you need that for 140. I took Stat 140 and am currently in 189 and I am finding the probability portion in 189 extactly what they taught in the last few weeks on 140. 140 was designed as a prerequisite for CS 189, Stat 154, and Data 102 (aka all the ML courses). That being said, I took 140 without 70, but it was my favorite class so far and I learned a lot. I did have friends who were really smart, took 70, and then dropped 126 cause it was too intense. I would recommend getting more feedback tho, especially from those who took 126. 

------

I got an A in 70 and probably went into 126 as an average student (made up for it with large effort in the second half in the class). I think if you got a B+, you will be on the very low end of the curve and you will probably struggle a lot; keep in mind, though, that Ramchandran is an amazing professor & also very nice so he gives >3.3 curves. So I'd say if you are serious about the ML track, take 126 and study beforehand. If you are not planning on graduate school, take prob 140 and make sure to take 189 with a professor who doesn't require 126/127, like Prof Shewchuk.

Edit: to reply to the below, if you are a student who can succeed in 126 and took 140 instead, then 140 still prepares you well. My advice is geared towards those who aren't able to do 126 and take 140 instead, then, you will likely find the level of mathematical maturity with a professor like Sahai much more difficult. 

------

I disagree with the answer above. Stat 140 is enough for 189, even with a professor that 'requires' 126. I took 189 with Sahai having taken Stat 140 beforehand, and felt perfectly well prepared by Stat 140 for the probability portion of the class.

children.subject: I'm taking 126 (for fun) right now, since I enjoyed the probability section of 70, but I can definitely understand how one might feel generally poorly prepared coming from that class (nothing really ever clicked for me in 70). I was also a bit intimidated by the level of 126, so one thing that really helped me prepare for this semester was actively reading through the first three chapters of the Bertsekas textbook that 126 uses (doing all examples on my own, doing the starred problems and proofs, and thoroughly reading through solutions for things I got wrong). All of this is available online, and I think doing this really helped probability make sense for me, so this would be helpful regardless of whether you choose to take 140 or 126. I'll also add that 126 office hours have been much less crowded than 70 office hours so far, so those have actually been invaluable for completing assignments. Also, the 126 TAs are great, and sections this semester are being taught with two TAs (one to lecture and one to answer questions), so that has been very helpful as well. Hope this helps!

Thank you all for your comments. They've been really helpful, seriously. I think I'm going to take Stat 140 (I have taken Data 8) so that I can really take the time to understand probability. Even though EECS 126 probably is a more comprehensive class, I don't think it will be that beneficial to me if I have to struggle through it as much as or more than how much I struggled through 70. Thanks again.

history.content:
I know this question has probably been asked a million times, but I'm having trouble deciding which one of these two courses to take.

I took CS 70 last semester, and did alright (B+). However, I found that most of the points I got on the final were from the discrete math section of the course. I was (and am) terrible with the probability portion, and I didn't really understand anything in the course after random variables. I was also behind for most of the second half of the semester because I got really burned out.

So, looking back on CS 70, I regret not trying harder to keep up with the material. I want to take another course in probability and actually learn the material this time. Now here's my dilemma; I want to take what will be the most useful class. Everyone on this forum pretty much agrees EECS 126 is more comprehensive, has more breadth, depth, etc. However, I was extremely confused, frustrated, and generally unhappy throughout the probability portion of CS 70. I felt like it went by way too fast, the homework was way harder than the examples in lecture, and I pretty much just skated by by the skin of my teeth.

I am worried that if I take EECS 126 the same thing will happen again. I really made an effort in CS 70 to read every note, watch every lecture, and go to all the discussions, but I still managed to fall behind and not really understand anything. I am also worried that if I take EECS 126 without really having the prerequisite knowledge from CS 70, I will just crash and burn.

The other option is Probability 140, which would teach all the information from CS 70 again from the ground up. I really like this option, but I don't want to take this and EECS 126, because it would be very redundant, and I don't really have space in my schedule. I'm not really worried about my grade in EECS 126 if I take it, but I want to learn as much as I can, and be prepared in case I choose to take CS 189 at some point. So I'm really at a loss at what I should take.

I don't know, does anyone have any advice for me, who has taken one or both of these classes? I'd appreciate it.
history.subject: Stat 140 vs. EECS 126
